name: River Styx
shortDescription: Sacred river marking the boundary between the living world and Underworld, by which gods swear unbreakable oaths
fullDescription: The River Styx (Greek: Œ£œÑœçŒæ, 'Hatred' or 'Detestation') is the principal river of the Underworld, forming the boundary between Earth and the realm of the dead. The goddess Styx personifies the river, and it circles the Underworld seven or nine times. The deceased must cross the Styx via Charon's ferry (paying with a coin placed in the mouth at burial) to reach Hades' kingdom. Most significantly, the Styx is the river by which the gods swear their most binding oaths‚Äîbreaking such an oath results in severe punishment including temporary loss of divine powers. Achilles was dipped in the Styx by his mother Thetis, making him invulnerable except for his heel. The river's dark waters possess both protective and destructive properties.

mythologyContexts.usage: Boundary between life and death; river of sacred oaths; source of Achilles' invulnerability

Styx as the oath river of the gods

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Styx symbolizes the absolute boundary between life and death, the liminal space of transition. Its use for divine oaths represents ultimate binding commitment.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: 'Crossing the Styx' became universal metaphor for dying. 'Stygian' means dark, gloomy, hellish.

originPoint.name: Mavroneri (Ancient Styx)
originPoint.description: Waterfall near Nonacris in Arcadia, Greece, identified in antiquity as the mythical River Styx. Mythologically, the river circles the Underworld.

firstAttestation.description: Appears in Homer as the dread oath river

timelinePosition.context: Fundamental underworld river from earliest Greek literature (c. 750 BCE)
